comment_data.body: The change and the motivation both make sense. Vim _does_ have its own comment plugin now, so they might also be open to this change for the same reason. The _only_ downside I can think of is that C did not support `//` comments until C99... but C99 is table stakes these days (and anyone who wants to use C89 can of course change their `'commentstring'` setting if they wish).

> Only problem is that we would now need to go through the "default" commentstrings and decide whether they should remain the current default or be changed to match C.

@clason Do you mean the comments in the source files? I don't think they need to be changed. (Also, they are /* %s \*/, while the present default is /\*%s\*/).

> Vim does have its own comment plugin now

It seems they have added it recently https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/5400a5d, but I'm on 9.0. I can open a issue/PR there too if required, but since neovim uses c.lua, this needs to be handled here too.

---

Edit: Rereading, do you mean the "default" commentstring when no commentstring is defined? `:h news-0.9` says they were changed to be empty.
I've hated the default commentstring for C for over a decade now. Let's change it!
Could we also do csharp then? `/*/*int b = 2;*/*/` is also invalid there

I don't think we should touch the default; the point is that some filetypes (that used the default commentstring) might wish/need to keep `/*%s*/` as commentstring even though C changed (otherwise we should change all files with ftplugins in Lua as they used the default string in Vim).

> I don't think we should touch the default; the point is that some filetypes (that used the default commentstring) might wish/need to keep `/*%s*/` as commentstring even though C changed (otherwise we should change all files with ftplugins in Lua as they used the default string in Vim).

The default was already changed (~~#22500~~ https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/22862). It is now empty, and we set `'commentstring'` for C specifically in its ftplugin file. So if other filetypes were depending on that value, they would have broken long ago.

>  So if other filetypes were depending on that value, they would have broken long ago.

They could be depending on the _specific_ value we explicitly set in their new ftplugins (which we added to account for the AWOL default commentstring).

Maybe I need to be more explicit. My question is whether the following `commentstring` values should _also_ be changed to match:

* `d`
* `cs`
* `css`
* `indent`
* `calendar`
* `xdefaults`

(I.e. did they rely on having the same commentstring as C, or on having the explicit value `/*%s*/`?)

I would expect the answer to be true (also change) for D and Csharp, false (do _not_ change) for CSS, and can't tell about the others.

Oh, and it's also important to check the ftplugins that explicitly import the C file:

* `objc`
* `ch` (whatever _that_ is)
* `xs` (which is a Perl extension, so I'd be surprised if it has even heard about C99...)

I went through all the ftplugins in runtime/ftplugin and came up with the following list of languages which will have the same problem as the above and can be changed. I also checked the dependencies (for eg, objc which uses C, and kwt, which uses Cpp). I don't have experience with all the languages, so please feel free to correct me.

| File | Present string | Suggested string |
| --- | --- | --- |
| calender.lua | '/\*%s\*/' | No idea about this |
| c.lua | '/\*%s\*/' | '// %s' |
| cs.lua | '/\*%s\*/'  | '// %s' |
| d.lua | '/\*%s\*/'  | '// %s' |
| dtrace.vim | /\*%s\*/ | Seems to be similar to D |
| indent.lua | '/\*%s\*/' | No idea about this |
| php.vim | /\*%s\*/ |  //\ %s |
| xdefaults.lua | '/\*%s\*/' | '! %s' |
| pascal.vim | {%s} | //\ %s |
| racket.vim | #\|\ %s\ \|# | ;\ %s |
| wat.vim | (;%s;) | //\ %s |

indent and calendar are such generic words that searching for calendar/indent language does not give relevant results.

Regarding `xs`,  I found [this](https://perldoc.perl.org/perlxs#Inserting-POD,-Comments-and-C-Preprocessor-Directives) doc which suggests that it's string should be `#\ %s`, but the present default is C/C++.

Also, kwt uses `runtime! cpp.vim`, which I would suggest to be changed to c.vim for ease of search in the future.

I think this is a bigger amount of changes than I am comfortable making here, to be honest. We should separate these into two sets:

1. update C comment style to C99 (which Vim does not use), including its direct dependents;
2. improve other commentstrings like `xs` where the default may be valid but is not optimal.

Set 2 can and should be changed upstream first, which would unblock set 1 for us. I'm afraid the procedure for changing multiple ftplugins upstream is a bit tedious, but maybe it can be done in coordination with the one by @ribru17 ?

It seems @ribru17's commit is regarding `//%s` vs `//\ %s`, so a bit tangential to this issue but should be first decided (so we fix on the conforming one for C/C++ too).

Should I open an issue upstream regarding 2?
Also, to be clear, are {c,cs,d,xdefaults}.lua considered in 1, and should be handled here?

Yes, that PR is unrelated except in the sense that it already changes a bunch of commentstrings, so I'm hoping for a "while we're already doing that we might as well" response instead of the usual.

In my view, only things where we already have our own ftplugin in Lua is in Set 1; the rest should be left for Vim to change (which means Set 1 is essentially blocked for now by `xs`).

I can update my PR: to make sure I understand, should I change C (of course making sure to check ones that inherit from it) from the default cms to `/*\ %s\ */`? Or does that fall under part 1? Maybe all places that use `setl cms&` should explicitly be set to also be given some padding?
I don't see why `xs` is blocking set 1? I just checked my installation of neovim, and the default commentstring for xs seems to be empty (it imports from c.vim, not c.lua, so it is not `/*%s*/`).

> I can update my PR: to make sure I understand, should I change C (of course making sure to check ones that inherit from it) from the default cms to /*\ %s\ */? Or does that fall under part 1? 

That falls under part 1 -- Vim uses `/*  */` comment style (unlike Neovim), so they will not want to change that.

> I don't see why xs is blocking set 1?

Because `xs` derives from C, and `//` is not valid. So we would have to break the link and deviate from Vim, which I don't want to do.

> (it imports from c.vim, not c.lua, so it is not /*%s*/).

Sorry, I missed that. It _should_ import `c.lua`, like `ftplugin/cpp.vim`. (Same goes for the other ftplugins that import `c.vim`.)

Alternative -- and probably better for cpp.vim as well -- would be keep the vim files identical to upstream and add lua versions that just set the correct commentstring. This would add half a dozen of them but not require any upstream changes.

> That falls under part 1 -- Vim uses `/* */` comment style (unlike Neovim), so they will not want to change that.

But shouldn't padding be added if other files using `cms&` are changed to be given padding? It would still use the `/**/` style, just with spaces. Otherwise C (and those inheriting from it) would be the only ones without space padding. Maybe I am misunderstanding your comment, though.

I'm no more sure about what is the correct commentstring for `xs` files.

[This](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/5c33815448e11b514678f39cecc74e68131d4628/runtime/ftplugin/c.vim#L35C38-L36C69) defines it to include `//` and `/* */` both, but [this](https://perldoc.perl.org/perlxs#Inserting-POD,-Comments-and-C-Preprocessor-Directives) specifies that both are incorrect. Can someone from vim-perl clarify this?

This is completely orthogonal to padding; I didn't mean for these changes to be part of your PR (they shouldn't), just to exploit the current mood for touching these files.

What we're talking here is changing commentstrings from `/*...*/` to `//...`.

> I'm no more sure about what is the correct commentstring for `xs` files.
> 
> [This](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/5c33815448e11b514678f39cecc74e68131d4628/runtime/ftplugin/c.vim#L35C38-L36C69) defines it to include `//` and `/* */` both, but [this](https://perldoc.perl.org/perlxs#Inserting-POD,-Comments-and-C-Preprocessor-Directives) specifies that both are incorrect. Can someone from vim-perl clarify this?

I wouldn't be surprised if this was broken from the start. Yes, please raise an issue at vim-perl (and ask them to contribute the changes, if any, to Vim).

From our side, here's what I propose to move this forward:

* for any ftplugin in Lua that sets the commentstring for a C-type language (which includes `indent`), change to `// %s`;
* for any ftplugin that includes a `runtime! ftplugin/c.vim`, add a separate ftplugin in Lua that sets the commentstring explicitly (as `// %s` if it's C-type, or the actually correct commentstring if it isn't).
* do not touch any other ftplugins; those are left for Vim to fix.

> This is completely orthogonal to padding; I didn't mean for these changes to be part of your PR

Totally; so it would be alright to change plugins using `setl cms&` on vim's side to use `/*\ %s\ */`? Just wanting to take note of this issue to make the vim PR more complete, but I don't want to do anything that will conflict here. But it sounds like that isn't the case
Yep, totally separate and no conflicts. This is only about changes to filetypes already affected by our divergence.

Hello. This issue broke my entire neovim workflow and made me switch to vscode until it's fixed. Cause there's no obvious workaround (nvchad is already not compatible with 0.9.x) and I'm supposed to do some productive work instead of trying to figure out why the hell it started commenting code like that (and moreover, failing to uncomment multiline comments) after the usual package upgrade.

Please don't push such buggy breaking changes into releases anymore.

Add `vim.bo.commentstring = '/*%s*/'` to your `ftplugin/<language>.lua` file to restore the previous behaviour.

Also, this PR is not yet in the release version of neovim, so are you doing productive work with neovim compiled from master? (Edit: There was a prerelease build, so it seems you are on the prerelease build?)

Finally, please be nice?

Also, I don't use NvChad, but you should probably raise that issue there since NvChad's last release date is after neovim's 0.9.5 release date.
